portfolio_context.constraints_note: Technology at 33% leaves room but should avoid over-concentration. Industrials and Energy also moderately elevated. Materials, Healthcare, and Consumer Discretionary most scalable sectors.

candidates.name: Eli Lilly and Company
candidates.catalyst: New obesity drug indication approved in early November; Q3 earnings beat with raised FY guidance.
candidates.fundamentals: Revenue +34% YoY, EPS beat by 11%, GLP-1 franchise accelerating with >$3.4B quarterly sales.
candidates.rationale: Healthcare exposure is only 9.7% in the portfolio, leaving ample room. LLY offers strong secular growth with defensive attributes and best-in-class GLP-1 category leadership.
candidates.recommendation: High-quality candidate for an 8–12% position without sector cap risk.

candidates.name: Caterpillar Inc.
candidates.catalyst: Infrastructure contract demand strong; November analyst upgrades citing multi-year backlog strength.
candidates.fundamentals: Revenue +16% YoY, margin expansion to 19%, record construction machinery backlog.
candidates.rationale: Industrials currently at 20%, below 45% cap. CAT adds durable-cycle exposure and infrastructure tailwinds complementing HWM and GE.
candidates.recommendation: Strong diversification candidate; fits well at 8–10% weight.

candidates.name: McDonald's Corporation
candidates.catalyst: Q3 global same-store sales +9%; new digital loyalty expansion launched in early November.
candidates.fundamentals: Revenue +14% YoY, EPS beat 7%, strong international growth.
candidates.relative_strength: Outperforming consumer discretionary peers by +6% over 12 weeks.
candidates.rationale: Consumer Discretionary is only 8.3% (RCL only). Adding a defensive consumer mega-cap offsets portfolio cyclicality and balances risk.
candidates.recommendation: Ideal for sector balancing; suitable for 8–10% position if consumer exposure desired.

candidates.name: NextEra Energy
candidates.catalyst: Wind and solar projects accelerated; November utility rate approval improved forward earnings outlook.
candidates.fundamentals: Revenue +18% YoY, EPS beat by 6%, strong renewable backlog.
candidates.rationale: Energy exposure is 18.6%, still below 45% cap. NEE is renewable-focused and does not overlap with NRG or GEV’s profiles. Provides defensive growth with clean-energy upside.
candidates.recommendation: Good candidate for 8–10% position, particularly for diversification beyond fossil-linked energy names.

candidates.name: Arista Networks
candidates.catalyst: Hyperscale AI data center demand surged; Q3 beat with raised 2025 revenue outlook.
candidates.fundamentals: Revenue +21% YoY, gross margin 63%, operating margin 41%.
candidates.relative_strength: Outperforming SMH by +9% and networking peers by +22% over 12 weeks.
candidates.rationale: Technology sits at 33%, below the 45% cap. ANET provides differentiated AI networking exposure compared with WDC/STX/PLTR’s segments.
candidates.recommendation: High-quality tech momentum pick; fits best as a tactical addition or tech replacement candidate.

screening_summary.quality_screen: 17 stocks with earnings beats and >40% institutional ownership
screening_summary.sector_diversification: 1 Healthcare, 1 Industrials, 1 Consumer Discretionary, 1 Energy, 1 Technology
screening_summary.notes: Portfolio has room for additional tech exposure but diversification preferred. LLY, CAT, and MCD best improve sector balance. All candidates include recent catalysts (within last 4 weeks).
